Whonix ™ Project Activities[edit]

Innovation[edit]

Table: Whonix ™ Innovation

Category Description
Anonymity
  • Thinking hard about obscure attacks on anonymity such as clock correlation deanonymization attacks and developing countermeasures; see TimeSync.
  • Adding support for multiple anonymity networks to cater to different user bases.
Invent mechanisms for rapid Debian packaging
  • genmkfile - easy and turbo packaging of scripts and configuration files.
  • Demonstrating how to write hassle free man pages.
    • For example, the following methodology is used for all related Whonix ™ packages.
    • Written in markdown.
    • Just three lines of packaging is required.
    • https://github.com/Whonix/tor-ctrl/blob/master/man/tor-ctrl.8.ronn
      • https://github.com/Whonix/tor-ctrl/blob/a12d73ed01068baf32db067811c208034ced87fd/debian/control#L9
      • https://github.com/Whonix/tor-ctrl/blob/1c326b232b1f328a6542ae51f3f3afa3e1e44a55/debian/rules#L17-L18
Holistic focus
  • Focusing on the anonymity and privacy field, without getting into unimportant details.
  • Understanding issues regular users are experiencing and creating a better user experience.
Develop concepts
  • Emergency Security News Notification
  • Permanent Takedown Attack Defender, proposal to defend against a permanent takedown threat
  • apt-revoker Check for Revocation Certificates before running apt
  • Package manager update security on/off switch
  • And much more.
Miscellaneous Maintaining a general interest in security matters, scrutinizing solutions, and connecting people. [1]

Cooperation[edit]

Table: Whonix ™ Cooperation

Category Description
Issue/bug reports Reporting issues or bugs at other projects, such as:
  • Qubes
  • VirtualBox
The Tor Project
  • Successfully communicate issues in the Tor ecosystem and do so whenever we find something. Some suggestions have been implemented and others accepted:
    • https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/query?reporter=proper&col=id&col=summary&col=status&col=type&col=priority&col=milestone&col=component&order=priority
    • https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/query?reporter=adrelanos&col=id&col=summary&col=type&col=status&col=priority&col=milestone&col=component&order=priority
  • Reporting any security/privacy/anonymity issues discovered, including some which could lead to deanonymization.

Please press on expand on the right for a list of references.

    • do something about TLS HELLO gmt_unix_time
    • get independent from host clock time / insecure NTP
    • use Valid-Until field to prevent downgrade attacks for deb.torproject.org
    • use sha256 or sha512 instead of sha1 for deb.torproject.org
    • deactivate Check for new messages on startup
    • deactive submit performance data
    • deactivate Check for new messages every 10 minutes
    • enable connection security by default
    • Remove "This Plugin is Disabled" click-through
    • set plugin.expose_full_path to false
    • Adapt Tor installer to allow users to avoid connecting to the public tor network
    • Add warning related to Identity correlation through circuit sharing
    • spoof history.length - browser.sessionhistory.max_entries
    • Linux TCP Initial Sequence Numbers may aid correlation
Other collaborative efforts/contributions
  • kloak - Keystroke Anonymization Tool [2]
  • https://secure-os.org/pipermail/desktops/
  • zuluCrypt [3]
Developer community
  • Coordination of an active developer community, see: Whonix ™ contributors.
  • Whonix ™ contributions:
    • founder adrelanos
    • developer troubadour
    • developer madaidan
    • former developer 0brand
    • developer HulaHoop
    • developer Jason Ayala
    • developer Algernon
    • developer Sirus Shahini
    • incomplete list
Miscellaneous
  • Flexible packaging to allow cherry-picking of functionality by privacy and non-privacy distributions alike: https://github.com/Whonix/anon-meta-packages/blob/master/debian/control
  • Providing all Whonix ™ improvements to Debian as reusable (by others) packages split by functionality: https://github.com/Whonix
  • Use many packages developed by Whonix ™ with Debian too.
  • Timely review and merging of contributions.

Mentoring[edit]

  • Google Summer of Code
  • Google Season of Docs (GSoD)
  • CS Student Capstone (Bachelor's Senior project) for Whonix

Education[edit]

Whonix ™ undertakes a broad range of educational activities, including:

  • Extensive Documentation covering technical aspects and operational security.
    • Security and anonymity matters are documented in detail, including unique material not covered elsewhere. [4]
    • Technical documentation is also provided, for example: Configuration Files.
  • Whonix ™ answers are seldom disputed; for example see answers by Patrick Schleizer on Tor Stack Exchange.
  • Operating a responsive forum, providing user support for the community.
  • Debian derivative development documentation, for example: About Debian Packaging

Maintenance[edit]

Whonix ™ maintenance activities are wide in scope and include:

  • Following developments in anonymity, security and privacy and formulating solutions. For example this apt bug led to the posting of a news item and instructions to safely resolve the matter.
  • Maintaining various components.
  • Ongoing development:
    • Refer to this subset list of Whonix ™ git commits; and
    • ~ 85 Whonix ™ source code repositories.
  • Keeping the whonix.org server safe and up-to-date with various webapps (website, wiki, forums and issue tracker).
  • Testing new packages.
  • Calling for testers, then reviewing and processing feedback from testers.
  • Creating downloadable Whonix ™ builds.
  • Keeping the community informed about recent developments at Whonix.
  • Porting to the next stable version of Debian. [5]
